member.name: M:VRage.Algorithms.MyPathFindingSystem`1.PrepareTraversal(`0,System.Predicate{`0},System.Predicate{`0},System.Predicate{VRage.Algorithms.IMyPathEdge{`0}})
member.summary:
Has to be called before any traversal of the pathfinding system using enumerators.
Several predicates can be supplied to the system that change the behavior of the traversal.
member.param: The vertex from which the traversal starts
If set, this predicate is applied to the output vertices so that we only get those that we are interested in.

This predicate allows to make vertices of the graph untraversable, blocking the paths through them. It is guaranteed to be called only once on every vertex when enumerating the graph or finding reachable vertices, but for pathfinding functions, this guarantee is no longer valid.
This predicate allows to make edges untraversable, blocking the paths through them.

members.member:
Fast representation for disjoint sets.
This data structure guarantees virtually constant time operations for union and finding the representative element of disjoint sets.

member.name: T:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator
member.summary: Generates IDs sequentially and reuses old IDs which are returned to pool by calling Return method. Protection count and time can be set to protect returned IDs. Protection is useful especially in multiplayer where clients can still have objects with those IDs.

member.name: F:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.m_maxId
member.summary: Max used id, zero is reserved and never used.

member.name: F:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.m_protecionCount
member.summary: Minimal number of items in reuse queue until first item can be taken.

member.name: F:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.m_reuseProtectionTime
member.summary: Minimal time if item spent in reuse queue until it can be returned. Units are arbitrary

member.name: F:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.m_timeFunc
member.summary: Function which returns current time, units are arbitrary and same as reuse protection time.

member.name: P:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.ReservedCount
member.summary: Number of reserved ids, zero is also reserved, but not counted.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.CreateWithStopwatch(System.TimeSpan,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates new sequence id generator with stopwatch to measure protection time.
member.param: Time to protect returned IDs.
Minimum number of IDs in protection queue, before first ID will be reused.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Algorithms.SequenceIdGenerator.Reserve(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Reserves first several IDs, so it's never returned by generator. Zero is never returned, when reservedIdCount is 2, IDs 1 and 2 won't be ever returned.
member.param: Number of reserved IDs which will be never returned by generator.

member.name: T:VRage.Library.Collections.MyBucketedPool`1
member.summary: A bucketed pool that allows collections or other objects with variable size to be pooled more efficiently.
member.remarks:
Using the provided bucketing function this class will separate pooled objects so that whenever they are requested we can provide an instance that is large enough for the required use.
In order to support any type of variable size object (and not just collections) the user has to provide their own callback to find the sie of an entry.
member.typeparam: The type of the pooled object.

member.name: T:VRage.Library.Collections.PoolManager
member.summary:
A simple thread safe manager for all sorts of pooled objects.
This

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Collections.PoolManager.Preallocate``1(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Preallocate a number of elements for a given object pool.
This call only produces an effect if the pool has not yet been initialized.
member.typeparam: The type of the pooled object.
member.param: The number of elements to preallocate, this can be zero.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Collections.PoolManager.Get``1
member.summary:
Get an instance from a pool.
Pooled resources represent data structures that are cached to prevent unnecessary memory allocations in time critical moments.
Pooled resources must always be return to the pool when no longer necessary.
member.typeparam: The type of the object to retrieve.
member.returns: Retrieve an instance of an object from the appropriate pool, if no pool exists one is created for the type.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Collections.PoolManager.Get``1(``0@)
member.summary:
Get an instance from a pool.
Pooled resources represent data structures that are cached to prevent unnecessary memory allocations in time critical moments.
Pooled resources must always be return to the pool when no longer necessary.
member.typeparam: The type of the object to retrieve.
member.returns: Retrieve an instance of an object from the appropriate pool, if no pool exists one is created for the type.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Collections.PoolManager.Return``1(``0@)
member.summary:
Return an object to it's pool.
Note that if no pool has been allocated for the object type this call does nothing.
If this type of behaviour is undesirable one may preallocate the pool . In this case a preallocation of size 0 ensures the pool exists but does not allocate any instances.
member.typeparam: The type of the object to return to the pool.
member.param: An object to return to a pool.

member.name: T:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1
member.summary: An implementation of a min-Priority Queue using a heap. Has O(1) .Contains()! See https://github.com/BlueRaja/High-Speed-Priority-Queue-for-C-Sharp/wiki/Getting-Started for more information
member.typeparam: The values in the queue. Must extend the FastPriorityQueueNode class

member.name: F:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Node.Priority
member.summary: The Priority to insert this node at. Must be set BEFORE adding a node to the queue (ideally just once, in the node's constructor). Should not be manually edited once the node has been queued - use queue.UpdatePriority() instead

member.name: F:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Node.QueueIndex
member.summary: Represents the current position in the queue

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Instantiate a new Priority Queue
member.param: initial memory size of the queue

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.#ctor
member.summary: Instantiate a new Priority Queue

member.name: P:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of nodes in the queue. O(1)

member.name: P:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.MaxSize
member.summary: Returns the maximum number of items that can be queued at once in this queue. Once you hit this number (ie. once Count == MaxSize), attempting to enqueue another item will cause undefined behavior. O(1)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Clear
member.summary: Removes every node from the queue. O(n) (So, don't do this often!)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Contains(`0)
member.summary: Returns (in O(1)!) whether the given node is in the queue. O(1)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Enqueue(`0,System.Int64)
member.summary: Enqueue a node to the priority queue. Lower values are placed in front. Ties are broken arbitrarily. If the queue is full, the result is undefined. If the node is already queued, the result is undefined. O(log n)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.HasHigherOrEqualPriority(`0,`0)
member.summary: Returns true if 'higher' has higher priority than 'lower', false otherwise. Note that calling HasHigherOrEqualPriority(node, node) (ie. both arguments the same node) will return true

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Dequeue
member.summary: Removes the head of the queue and returns it. If queue is empty, result is undefined O(log n)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Resize(System.Int32)
member.summary: Resize the queue so it can accept more nodes. All currently queued nodes are remain. Attempting to decrease the queue size to a size too small to hold the existing nodes results in undefined behavior O(n)

member.name: P:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.First
member.summary: Returns the head of the queue, without removing it (use Dequeue() for that). If the queue is empty, behavior is undefined. O(1)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.UpdatePriority(`0,System.Int64)
member.summary: This method must be called on a node every time its priority changes while it is in the queue. Forgetting to call this method will result in a corrupted queue! Calling this method on a node not in the queue results in undefined behavior O(log n)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.Remove(`0)
member.summary: Removes a node from the queue. The node does not need to be the head of the queue. If the node is not in the queue, the result is undefined. If unsure, check Contains() first O(log n)

member.name: M:VRage.Library.FastPriorityQueue`1.IsValidQueue
member.summary: Should not be called in production code. Checks to make sure the queue is still in a valid state. Used for testing/debugging the queue.

member.summary: Discards old frame (keeps one older) and interpolates between two samples using interpolator. Returns interpolator There must be at least one sample!

members.member:
Over a given set of elements W this class maintains two subsets A and B such that A B = , A B = W, with constant time operations for moving elements from one set to the other.
Both subsets are individually iterable, as well as the whole W.
The order of elements in either set is never preserved.
When using this class with value types beware that they will be duplicated internally. Prefer to use class types or some form of lightweight reference with this.

member.name: T:VRage.Library.Utils.MyRandom
member.summary: Original C# implementation which allows settings the seed.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Utils.MyRandom.SetSeed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets new seed, only use this method when you have separate instance of MyRandom. Setting seed for RNG used for EntityId without reverting to previous state is dangerous. Use PushSeed for EntityId random generator.

member.name: T:VRage.Library.Utils.SortUtil
member.summary: Provides utilities for more exotic sorting.

member.name: M:VRage.Library.Utils.SortUtil.TopologicalSort``1(System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0},System.Func{``0,System.Collections.Generic.IList{``0}},System.Func{System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Boolean})
member.summary: Taking a list as a directed graph this method produces the topological ordering of it's vertices.
member.remarks:
This method takes an optional argument .
When provide this callback is invoked for every cycle found in the graph. Each time the call may return true to signify that the cycle should just be ignored, or false to mean that the sorting operation should be aborted.
If the argument is not provide cycles are always fatal.
If the sorting is aborted the original list remains unmodified.
member.typeparam: Type of the list item.
member.param: The list to order.
Get the vertices pointed to by a given item.
Delegate invoked to handle any cycles found.
member.returns: Whether the sorting operation was successful (there were no cycles or all off them were ignored).

summary.para: A set of integer numbers optimized for sets with long consecutive runs. Each interval is stored as two values in m_list: the lower and the upper bound.

member.summary: Splits the list into two. This list's end will be the node pointed by newLastPosition and the newly created list will begin with the next node.
member.param: Enumerator that points to the new last position in the list.

New number of elements in this list. If set to -1, it is calculated automatically, but that would make the split an O(N) operation. Beware: If you set this parameter, be sure to always set the correct number, otherwise, you'd cause both lists (this one and the returned one) to return a wrong number of elements in the future.
member.returns: The newly created list

member.summary:
Enqueue a piece of work to be executed by all workers.
This differs from regular enqueue in that the task is scheduled for each worker of the requested group, , if no group Id is provided then the default group is used.
member.param: The work to be executed.
The worker group to execute this work. If none or Null is provided then the default is taken.
Maximum number of workers that will be allowed work on this task. -1 means all.

member.summary:
Enqueue a piece of work to be executed by all workers.
This differs from regular enqueue in that the task is scheduled for each worker.
member.param: The work to be executed.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.IWorkerManager.AddCompletion(VRage.ParallelWorkers.WorkId,VRage.ParallelWorkers.ICompletion)
member.summary: Request that the provided completion object be invoked upon completion of the task identified by the given work id.
member.param: The id of the work to listen to.
The completion callback to be invoked upon the work finishing.
member.remarks: The completion object will be invoked on the thread executing the work. Unless it has already completed, in which case it is invoked immediately by this call.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.IWorkerManager.ExecutePendingWork(VRage.ParallelWorkers.WorkId,VRage.ParallelWorkers.IWork)
member.summary: Execute a work item that has already been queued.
member.remarks:
This call is akin to stealing a work item from the queue.
If the work is to be carried by multiple workers the caller will act as if it were one of them.
member.param: The id of the work to execute.
The work item to execute.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.IWorkerManager.WaitOn(VRage.ParallelWorkers.WorkId)
member.summary:
Wait on a piece work to be finished.
This will block the calling thread until all workers that might be processing the work are finished.
member.param: The id of the work to wait on.
member.remarks:
Calling this on a worker may deadlock.
Workers have so called 'personal' queues of work items. These queues are appended to by calls to EnqueueAll. If a worker waits on a task that is in it's personal queue it will then deadlock that worker. Any other thread that waits on a task that worker would perform will likewise be stuck.
To avoid that be very careful with the tasks you wait on inside workers, preferably always wait on tasks that are issued with the Enqueue call as those can be performed by any worker in the group, which means as long as at least one is idle it will not deadlock.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.IWorkerManager.WaitAll(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary:
Wait on all workers to be idle.
This call will only return after the specified timeout or when all workers are idle.
member.returns: Whether the call returned because all workers became idle (true) or because the timeout was reached.

member.param: The thread to lookup
member.returns: Whether the argument thread represents a worker.

member.summary: Tell whether the current thread is a worker.

member.returns: Whether the argument thread represents a worker.

Get the number of workers in a group.
If this worker does not have that group this method returns 0.
member.param: The id of the worker group to query, if Null is provided the default is used.
member.returns: The number of workers in the found group, or zero.

member.name: T:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.CompletionBuffer
member.summary: Represents a completion queue.

member.name: F:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.m_ownedCompletionBuffer
member.summary: The completion buffer owned by the current thread.

member.name: F:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.m_currentCompletionBuffer
member.summary: Stack of completion buffers for callbacks on the current thread.
member.remarks:
When a work starts executing it will set the callback based on the thread that scheduled it.
Since work can be executed recursively (via waiting) we need to maintain the buffers as a stack, to make sure that no completion winds up in the wrong thread.

member.name: F:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.m_defaultCompletionBuffer
member.summary: The default completion buffer, on the 'main' thread.

member.name: F:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.Buffers
member.summary: Per thread completion buffer set.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.RunCallbacks
member.summary:
Run all callbacks for the current thread.
This must be called once before any work can be scheduled to be completed on the current thread.
member.remarks:
Completion callbacks are asynchronous calls that can be queued to execute after some parallel work is finished. They are a non-blocking and thread safe alternative to waiting ().
Completion callbacks are scheduled based on the target buffer for the current thread. These can be set in a few ways:
Main thread callback buffer: The *main thread* (the thread that called one of the Init methods) will automatically receive a buffer and be designated a callback runner.
Callback runner buffer: Any thread that invokes RunCallbacks is registered as a callback runner, and get's it's own buffer. An example of this behavior is a render thread, that wants callbacks for it's jobs to be executed by it and not the main thread.
Worker buffer stack: Workers maintain a stack of destination buffers. While they cannot be callback runners themselves they will have the callback buffer set based on the thread that scheduled the currently executing job. That way if a job is scheduled in a parallel it will complete on the same thread as the job that scheduled it.
If work is scheduled with completion from a thread that is neither a worker or a callback runner it will complete on the Main Thread.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.Workers.GetCurrentCompletionThread
member.summary: Get the thread that is scheduled to run completions for the current thread.
member.returns: The thread that currently is set to execute completions for newly scheduled works.

member.summary:

member.summary: Request that the provided completion object be invoked upon completion of the task identified by the given work id.
member.param: The id of the work to listen to.
The completion callback to be invoked upon the work finishing.
member.remarks: The completion object will be invoked on the thread executing the work. Unless it has already completed, in which case it is invoked immediately by this call.

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.WorkerManager.WaitOn(VRage.ParallelWorkers.WorkId)
member.summary:
Wait on a piece work to be finished.
This will block the calling thread until all workers that might be processing the work are finished.
member.param: The id of the work to wait on.
member.remarks:
When waiting on another work inside a worker be sure that there are no wait cycles, such as two tasks that both wait on each other.
Cases where workers wait on items in their own, or other worker's queues are resolved via work stealing, so they do not deadlock (but they might brake the FIFO ordering of the work queues).

member.name: M:VRage.ParallelWorkers.WorkerManager.WaitAll(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan})
member.summary:
Wait on all workers to be idle.
This call will only return after the specified timeout or when all workers are idle.
member.returns: Whether the call returned because all workers became idle (true) or because the timeout was reached.

If the work item can be executed on multiple workers the current thread will participate.
Otherwise if the work is not scheduled yet it will be removed from the queue and executed on the current thread.
If the work has reached it's execution limit this method suspends the calling thread until the work is finished.

member.summary: Represents a dependency between two components.

member.summary: Flags specifying how a dependency is handled.

member.name: F:VRage.Utils.DependencyResolve.DependencyFlags.Recursive
member.summary: Implicitly depend on every child type as well.
member.remarks: On some object types dependencies are always recursive, in those cases this flag is ignored.

member.name: F:VRage.Utils.DependencyResolve.DependencyFlags.Critical
member.summary: Mark this dependency as critical, meaning the annotated object cannot be used without the object that it depends on.
member.remarks: Critical dependencies when not met will cause a , unless the component depended on allows it's instantiation in that case (see ).

member.name: F:VRage.Utils.DependencyResolve.DependencyFlags.Reverse
member.summary: Marks a dependency as having reversed ordering.
member.remarks: A reverse dependency expresses the same object requirement relation with an inverse ordering relation (i.e.: The first type still depends on the second but should be placed before the later in the parent container).

member.name: F:VRage.Utils.DependencyResolve.DependencyResolveError.MissingCriticalDependency
